Universi~_" of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan Received 12 December 1994; revised 20 February 1995; accepted 20 February 1995 Abstract A significant effect of the support on the catalytic activity of palladium-based catalysts for methanol synthesis from carbon dioxide and hydrogen was observed, where Pd/Ga203 was more active than Cu/ZnO by a factor of 2 in yield and 20 in turnover frequency Keywords: Methanol synthesis; Palladium catalyst; Support effect The synthesis of methanol from carbon dioxide and hydrogen has recently attracted interest as a pathway to utilize carbon dioxide as a raw material for chemicals. It is widely accepted that Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/A1203 are active catalysts for methanol formation from carbon monoxide and hydrogen as well as from carbon dioxide and hydrogen. The synergetic effect between copper and ZnO has been reported by several researchers, where the mechanism was explained by a spillover effect of hydrogen migrating between the ZnO and copper surfaces [ 1,2] or the stabilization of active Cu+ species by ZnO, on the copper surface [3,4]. On the other hand, palladium catalysts are also known to be active for methanol synthesis by hydro- genation of carbon monoxide. Bell and co-workers have reported [5,6] a support effect of palladium catalysts containing metal oxides such as SiO2, TiO2, MgO, A1203, La203, and ZrO2 on the activity of methanol formation from carbon mon- oxide and hydrogen, and found that the Pd/La203 catalyst showed the highest * Corresponding author. Fujitani et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 125 (1995) LI99-L202 activity, while Pd/ZnO exhibited the highest selectivity toward methanol forma- tion. However, the support effect of palladium catalysts in methanol synthesis from carbon dioxide and hydrogen has not yet been reported to our knowledge. In this communication, we report a significant support effect on the activity of palladium catalysts toward methanol formation by the hydrogenation of carbon dioxide and also we report the finding that Pd/Ga203 is a super-active catalyst for methanol synthesis, being more active than the Cu/ZnO catalyst. A series of palladium catalysts were prepared by the coprecipitation method. An aqueous solution of Na2CO3 ( 1.1 M) together with a mixed solution of palladium and metal oxide nitrates (total metal concentration = 1.0 M) was added dropwise to distilled water at 300 K. The precipitate was aged in the mixed solution at 343 K for 1 h, followed by a thorough washing with distilled water. Subsequently, the precipitate was dried overnight in an oven at 383 K, calcined in air at 623 K for 2 h, and finally screened to size between 60 and 80 mesh. The catalysts were usually loaded to a level of 10 wt.-% Pd. The Pd/SiO2 catalyst was prepared by an alkoxide method. The catalyst ( 1.0 g), fixed in a reactor, was reduced in a gas mixture of hydrogen (10%) and helium (90%) at 523 K with a total pressure of 5.0 MPa. The hydrogenation of carbon dioxide was then carried out at 523 K in a flow reactor by feeding a gas mixture of hydrogen and carbon dioxide with a mole ratio of He/ CO2 = 3. The total pressure of hydrogen and carbon dioxide was 5.0 MPa, and the typical reaction time was 2 h. The reaction products were analyzed using gas chromatographs directly connected to the reactor. Carbon monoxide chemisorption measurements were carried out at 303 K using a conventional glass-made vacuum system. The amount of carbon monoxide required for monolayer coverage of the palladium metal surface was estimated by extrapolating the flat part of an adsorption isotherm to the zero of the equilibrium pressure for adsorption. This assumes that one carbon monoxide molecule can be adsorbed on each surface palladium atom. The reaction data for the hydrogenation of carbon dioxide and the uptake of carbon monoxide over the various supported palladium catalysts are summarized in Table 1. The activities and selectivities at the steady state of the reaction at 523 K and 5.0 MPa were measured after passing the reactants over the catalysts for 2 h. It is clear that the Ga203 supported palladium catalyst is superior to Cu/ZnO with respect to the methanol yield and the methanol selectivity. The methanol yield of 10.1% for Pd/Ga20~ at the indicated reaction conditions indicates that this is a super-active catalyst for methanol synthesis as compared to the Cu/ZnO (4.2%) catalyst, which was previously known to be the most active catalyst. In turnover frequency (TOF), Pd/Ga203 is 20 times more active than Cu/ZnO. The effect of the support on the methanol yield and selectivity is found to be significant, with the different support metal oxides in the following order Ga203 > ZnO > A1203 > TiO2 = CrzO3 > SiO2 = ZrO2. TOF for Pd/Ga203 in Table 1 is higher than that of Pd/SiO2 by two orders of magnitude. Although the carbon dioxide conver- sion for Pd/TiO2 and Pd/ZnO is relatively high as shown in Table 1, the carbon monoxide selectivity for the catalysts is much higher than the methanol selectivity, T. The lack of any activity of Pd/SiO2 toward the RWGS reaction indicates that metallic palladium alone, which is the major part of the surface palladium atoms in a Pd/SiO2 catalyst, does not catalyze the RWGS reaction. It is considered that the RWGS reaction proceeds mainly on the metal oxides such as A1203, TiO2 or ZnO, a view based on previous results of the RWGS over Rh/A1203 and Rh/TiO2 that spillover hydrogen atoms from rhodium particles react with carbon dioxide adsorbed on the surface of A1203 and TiO2 to form formate species as an intermediate during the RWGS reaction [7]. The inertness of Pd/SiO2 also implies that metallic palladium alone has little catalytic activity for methanol for- mation. The significant difference in TOF between various metal oxides used as a support suggests that the active species involve Pd" + species as reported by Dries- sen et al. [8], who have clearly shown a linear relationship between the methanol synthesis activity from CO + H2 and the amount of Pd"+ measured by X-ray fluo- rescence on a La or Mg doped Pd/SiO2 catalyst. That is, the amount of Pd"+ may be quite different for palladium catalysts containing various metal oxides. We have reported that both Cu + and Cuspecies are active for methanol formation from CO2 + H2, and that the Cu+ species is considered to be stabilized by ZnO~ (x= 0- 1) migrated from ZnO onto the copper surface [3,4]. We also found that Cu/ Ga203 is more active than Cu/ZnO for methanol formation from CO2 + H2 [ 3,9]. Accordingly, we postulate that the excellent activity of Pd/Ga203 is due to the optimal amount of Pd"+ (0 < n < 2) stabilized by GabOn, on the surface of palladium.
